criteria.name: Headline Clarity
criteria.description: Can audience understand the core message in 10 seconds?

scoring.1: No clear headline, or headline is vague/generic. Reader doesn't know what message is about.
scoring.2: Headline exists but is vague or buries key insight. Requires reading body to understand point.
scoring.3: Headline clearly states topic and general direction. Reader gets gist but not full insight.
scoring.4: Headline captures core message with specificity. Reader understands essence without reading body.
scoring.5: Compelling headline that captures essence, creates curiosity, and uses concrete specifics. Impossible to misunderstand.

red_flags: Can't summarize message in one sentence
Headline describes format not content ('Memo on X' vs 'We should do X because Y')
Buries insight in paragraph 3 instead of headline

criteria.name: Structure and Flow
criteria.description: Is narrative easy to follow with logical progression?

scoring.1: No clear structure. Random collection of points without logical connection.
scoring.2: Some structure but jumps around. Reader confused about how points relate or what comes next.
scoring.3: Clear structure with distinct sections. Logical flow but transitions could be smoother.
scoring.4: Well-organized structure with smooth transitions. Each point builds on previous. Easy to follow.
scoring.5: Exemplary narrative arc. Points flow naturally, build tension/resolution, guide reader seamlessly from problem to action.

red_flags: No clear progression (flat list of facts)
Conclusion doesn't follow from body (non sequitur)

criteria.name: Evidence Quality
criteria.description: Are claims backed by concrete, credible proof?

scoring.1: No evidence. Claims without support. Asks for blind trust.
scoring.2: Minimal evidence. Vague statements ('studies show', 'many customers') without specifics.
scoring.3: Adequate evidence. Some data/examples provided but missing sources or context.
scoring.4: Strong evidence. Specific data with sources, concrete examples, comparisons for context.
scoring.5: Comprehensive proof. Multiple evidence types (quantitative, qualitative, examples), sources cited, limitations acknowledged.

red_flags: Cherry-picked data without showing full picture
Anecdotes presented as data ('one customer said' as proof of trend)

criteria.name: Audience Fit
criteria.description: Is message tailored to audience's expertise, concerns, and constraints?

scoring.1: Wrong audience fit. Jargon for non-experts, or dumbed-down for experts. Ignores their concerns.
scoring.2: Partial fit. Some mismatch in sophistication or doesn't address key concerns audience has.
scoring.3: Good fit. Appropriate sophistication level, addresses main concerns, reasonable length.
scoring.4: Excellent fit. Matches expertise, directly addresses concerns, appropriate tone and length, uses their language.
scoring.5: Perfect fit. Deeply understands audience, anticipates objections, uses analogies from their domain, feels personalized.

red_flags: Length mismatches time available (5-page email for busy executive)

criteria.name: Storytelling Techniques
criteria.description: Uses specificity, shows vs tells, humanizes data, builds tension?

scoring.1: No storytelling. Dry recitation of facts or feature list. No narrative arc.
scoring.2: Minimal storytelling. Mostly facts with occasional story elements. Tells more than shows.
scoring.3: Good storytelling. Uses some techniques (specifics, examples, data humanization). Shows and tells.
scoring.4: Strong storytelling. Consistently shows vs tells, uses specifics, humanizes data, builds some tension.
scoring.5: Masterful storytelling. Vivid specifics, shows throughout, data becomes human stories, tension and resolution arc.

red_flags: Tells instead of shows ('this is great' vs concrete evidence it's great)
Data dump without interpretation or humanization
No narrative arc (flat delivery of information)

criteria.name: Accountability and Honesty
criteria.description: Takes ownership, acknowledges risks/limitations, no blame-shifting?

scoring.1: No accountability. Passive voice, blame-shifting, or hiding responsibility.
scoring.2: Weak accountability. Some ownership but uses weasel words or deflects.
scoring.3: Adequate accountability. Takes responsibility, but doesn't fully acknowledge limitations.
scoring.4: Strong accountability. Clear ownership, acknowledges risks and limitations honestly.
scoring.5: Exemplary accountability. Named ownership, vulnerable honesty about uncertainties, acknowledges past mistakes if relevant.

red_flags: Passive voice hides actors ('mistakes were made' vs 'I made mistakes')
Blame external factors without acknowledging internal role
Misleading by omission (hiding risks or downsides)

criteria.name: Actionability (Call-to-Action)
criteria.description: Is CTA clear, specific, achievable, and time-bound?

scoring.1: No CTA, or completely vague ('think about it', 'be better').
scoring.2: CTA exists but vague or passive. Unclear what to do or who should do it.
scoring.3: Clear CTA but missing timeline, owner, or specifics on how to do it.
scoring.4: Strong CTA. Specific action, clear owner, deadline, achievable.
scoring.5: Perfect CTA. Specific, achievable, time-bound, clear owner, low-friction next step provided (link, meeting invite, etc).

criteria.name: Tone Appropriateness
criteria.description: Does tone match situation (crisis, celebration, persuasion, etc)?

scoring.1: Tone completely wrong. Casual for crisis, or somber for celebration.
scoring.2: Tone somewhat off. Misreads situation or audience expectations.
scoring.3: Tone mostly appropriate. Minor mismatches but generally fits.
scoring.4: Tone fits well. Appropriate formality, urgency, and emotion for situation.
scoring.5: Tone perfect. Nuanced match to situation, builds appropriate emotional connection, feels authentic.

red_flags: Hype/marketing speak for internal honest conversation

criteria.name: Transparency
criteria.description: Are assumptions, data sources, and limitations explicit?

scoring.1: Opaque. No visibility into how conclusions reached, what's assumed, or data sources.
scoring.2: Minimal transparency. Some info provided but key assumptions or limitations hidden.
scoring.3: Adequate transparency. Main assumptions and sources stated, but some gaps.
scoring.4: High transparency. Assumptions explicit, sources cited, limitations acknowledged.
scoring.5: Full transparency. Shows work, cites sources, states assumptions, acknowledges limitations, distinguishes facts from speculation.

red_flags: No acknowledgment of limitations or uncertainties
Facts and speculation mixed without distinction

criteria.name: Credibility
criteria.description: Does narrative build trust through vulnerability, track record, or expert validation?

scoring.1: No credibility signals. Asks for trust without earning it.
scoring.2: Weak credibility. Some signals (e.g., 'trust me') but not substantiated.
scoring.3: Adequate credibility. Track record or external validation mentioned.
scoring.4: Strong credibility. Combines multiple signals: vulnerability, track record, expert validation, data transparency.
scoring.5: Exceptional credibility. Vulnerable honesty, demonstrated track record, expert validation, shows calibration (past predictions vs outcomes).

red_flags: No track record or validation provided
Appeals to authority without substance ('experts agree')

Low-Stakes.description: Routine updates, internal announcements, FYI communications
success_indicators: Message is clear and quickly understood
acceptable_tradeoffs: Can be more concise at expense of storytelling

Medium-Stakes.description: Product announcements, project updates, recommendations needing approval
acceptable_tradeoffs: Some complexity acceptable if audience has time
Can be longer if stakes warrant detail

High-Stakes.description: Executive decisions, crisis communications, investor updates, major changes
focus_criteria: All criteria, especially Accountability, Evidence Quality, Credibility, Transparency
success_indicators: Full transparency on assumptions and risks
acceptable_tradeoffs: Can be longer if needed for completeness

Technical to Non-Technical.description: Explaining technical concepts/decisions to business stakeholders
key_patterns: Focus on business impact, not technical implementation
Show with concrete examples, not abstract concepts

Executive Communication.description: Board updates, CEO memos, investor relations
key_patterns: Front-load conclusions (BLUF - Bottom Line Up Front)

Customer-Facing.description: Product announcements, incident communications, customer updates
key_patterns: Lead with customer impact (not internal process)

Change Management.description: Org changes, process changes, difficult news
key_patterns: Show path from here to there
Lead with facts (what happened, when, impact)
Take accountability (no passive voice or blame-shifting)
State what you're doing (concrete actions with timeline)
Commit to transparency (when they'll hear next)

common_failure_modes.symptoms: Important insight appears in paragraph 3 or buried in middle of long text.
common_failure_modes.consequences: Busy audience never sees main point. Decisions delayed or made without full context.
common_failure_modes.fix: Move most important insight to headline and first sentence. Use inverted pyramid (most important first).

common_failure_modes.symptoms: Deck with 50 bullet points, no narrative thread connecting them.
common_failure_modes.consequences: Audience can't follow logic, points don't build, no memorable takeaway.
common_failure_modes.fix: Use bullets to support narrative, not replace it. Each slide should have one key point.

common_failure_modes.symptoms: Technical terms for non-technical audience, or dumbed-down language for experts.
common_failure_modes.consequences: Audience either confused or insulted. Message doesn't land.
common_failure_modes.fix: Match sophistication to audience. Define jargon when needed. Use analogies from their domain.

common_failure_modes.symptoms: Lists metrics without context or insight. 'Churn is 3.2%, NPS is 58, CAC is $1,150.'
common_failure_modes.consequences: Audience doesn't know what data means or what to do with it.
common_failure_modes.fix: Lead with insight, support with data. 'We're retaining customers well (3.2% churn is top quartile) but they're expensive to acquire ($1,150 CAC = 18-month payback).'

common_failure_modes.symptoms: CTA like 'Let's be more customer-focused' or 'Think about this'.
common_failure_modes.consequences: No one does anything. Message dies without action.
common_failure_modes.fix: Specific action, owner, timeline. 'Sarah, approve $50K budget by Friday' or 'Each team should interview 5 customers by month-end using guide [link].'

common_failure_modes.symptoms: Recommendation without showing cost of inaction. 'We should improve X.'
common_failure_modes.consequences: Audience doesn't prioritize. Request ignored in favor of urgent items.
common_failure_modes.fix: Show opportunity cost. 'Page load time is 2.5s, costing us 30% of conversions ($800K annually). Optimizing to 1s recovers $240K in year 1.'

common_failure_modes.symptoms: Claims causal relationship based on correlation. 'Feature X increased, then revenue grew, so X caused growth.'
common_failure_modes.consequences: Wrong decisions based on spurious relationships. Waste resources on non-drivers.
common_failure_modes.fix: Be explicit about causation vs correlation. If claiming causation, show mechanism or use causal inference methods.

common_failure_modes.symptoms: 'Mistakes were made', 'The decision was reached', 'It was determined that...'
common_failure_modes.consequences: Erodes trust. Audience doesn't know who's responsible or in control.
common_failure_modes.fix: Use active voice with named actors. 'I made mistakes', 'The exec team decided', 'Based on our analysis, I recommend...'

interpretation.1.0-2.0: Inadequate. Major issues with clarity, evidence, or audience fit. Do not deliver. Revise significantly.
interpretation.2.0-3.0: Needs improvement. Basic structure present but weak evidence, poor storytelling, or mismatched tone. Acceptable only for low-stakes FYI messages.
interpretation.3.0-3.5: Acceptable. Clear message with adequate evidence. Suitable for routine communications and internal updates.
interpretation.3.5-4.0: Good. Compelling narrative with strong evidence and clear action. Suitable for medium-stakes product announcements, recommendations.
interpretation.4.0-5.0: Excellent. Masterful storytelling, comprehensive evidence, builds credibility and trust. Suitable for high-stakes executive/crisis/customer communications.
